title: 111_hr6055
content: The Act may be cited as the "Accounts Receivable Insurance Program Act". Congress finds that small manufacturers are disproportionately affected by delays in payments of accounts receivable, especially during economic slowdowns. This leads to disruptions in the supply chain and hinders their ability to purchase raw materials, hire workers, and access credit. Additional assurance is needed to ensure customers pay their accounts on time. Small suppliers face cash flow issues due to delayed payments from downstream suppliers, particularly in financially troubled industries like the auto sector. Lenders view these suppliers as high risk, making it difficult for them to access credit. Government-backed receivables insurance could help middle-market companies secure the necessary credit lines for their daily operations. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. For the purpose of this Act, definitions include financial institution as an establishment engaged in financial transactions and insurance institution as primarily involved in underwriting annuities and insurance policies. The term "guarantee" has the same meaning. The term "guarantee" has the same meaning as in the Federal Credit Reform Act of 1990. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Treasury. SEC. 4. ACCOUNTS RECEIVABLE INSURANCE. The government establishes a program to provide insurance for small manufacturers' accounts receivable, guaranteeing payment terms through financial or insurance institutions. Small manufacturing businesses can apply for participation by submitting an application with required information. The program provides insurance for small manufacturers' accounts receivable, guaranteeing payment terms through financial or insurance institutions. Small manufacturing businesses can apply by submitting required information. Financial institutions cannot deny applications based solely on cash flow or customer industry classification. If a business defaults, the institution can demand payment from the Secretary for a fee and the remaining balance will be paid by the Secretary. The program offers insurance for small manufacturers' accounts receivable through financial or insurance institutions. If a small business defaults, the institution can request payment from the Secretary, but must show efforts to collect the debt first. Financial institutions are not eligible for guarantees if they insured the accounts receivable. The program offers insurance for small manufacturers' accounts receivable through financial or insurance institutions. Funding of up to $500,000,000 is available to the Secretary for guarantee costs without further appropriation. The Secretary cannot enter into any new contracts for guarantees after December 31, 2011. The Secretary must issue regulations within 90 days of the enactment of this Act to carry out the purposes of this section.
